snippet: A number of officials make the case that, if a deal is reached, surveillance of Iran will intensify and covert action may become more important to ensure that Iran does not import critical materials or pursue a covert path to a bomb.
abstract: American intelligence agencies have engaged in covert activity against Iranian nuclear program, even as Pres Obama's administration has been in negotiations about country's plans; administration officials rarely acknowledge degree to which covert activities have influenced Iranian decision to engage in negotiations; officials say that if agreement is reached, surveillance and covert action may become even more important.

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD

lead_paragraph: A number of officials make the case that, if a deal is reached, surveillance of Iran will intensify and covert action may become more important to ensure that Iran does not import critical materials or pursue a covert path to a bomb.

headline.main: Unstated Factor in Iran Talks: Threat of Nuclear Tampering
headline.print_headline: Unstated Factor in Iran Talks: Threat of Nuclear Tampering
